A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
From the point at which Luke takes the light saber held out for him by plucky young Rey\, and throws it into the water behind him\, it's plain to see that the creators have 'Let the past die'. More than that\, they killed it.

At the crux of the successful original trilogy\, and to a lesser extent the prequels\, there was a unique seriousness about the films. This was effectively written off as something of history\, as even the most serious characters found themselves reduced to mere comic relief in certain scenes. Take for example\, Luke drinking milk from a hideous alien beast\, throwing a lightsaber passed down through generations into the sea. Leia's quibbling with Poe\, and even (unintentionally comical) transforming into superman ever so briefly to fly back towards the ship\, stopping her from having a poignant meaningful death in the films.

Between cutting short the suspense of the origins of Snoke\, the somewhat meaningless introduction of Benicio Del Toro's thief character\, the anti-climactic death of Phasma and the lack of fanfare with the deaths of series stalwarts such as Admiral Akbar\, we see no care at all taken towards people who enjoy the original series or even storylines that were introduced by The Force Awakens. Add to this\, any storylines introduced in the Last Jedi hold no interest leading into the next film.

The message at the end of the film is clear; the old resistance is dying\, it's up to a new resistance to take up the fight. It's only unfortunate that with meaningless deaths to original and recognizable characters\, and the removal of Snoke as a mysterious and interesting villain\, I do not care too much for this new resistance or its fight.
